content.description:
R. C. Punnett conducted experiments on the inheritance of traits in the sweet pea, Lathyrus odoratus. In one experiment, he crossed two different true-breeding sweet pea plant strains, one with erect petals and long pollen, and the other with hooded petals and round pollen. All the offspring (<math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> generation) had erect petals and long pollen (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Sweet pea plant cross

content.question: Which of the following questions would be most useful to researchers trying to determine the role of meiosis in the <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> phenotypic frequencies?

choices.label: What is the molecular mechanism underlying the dominance of erect petals and long pollen?
Which phenotypes give pea plants the highest level of fitness: erect or hooded petals and long or round pollen?
How do the phases of meiosis differ between sweet pea plants and other organisms?
What is the recombination frequency between the genes for petal shape and pollen shape?

content.answer: What is the recombination frequency between the genes for petal shape and pollen shape?
